channel.title: [Help] How do I get a Java program to "silently" connect to a URL
channel.description:
By silent I mean: Connect to a URL without having to open a web browser. I need this for an auth system I'm making.
Here's an example of a url I want the program to connect to: [code]http://blablabla.com/blabla.php?user=blabla&pass=blabla[/code]
~Dizzy

item.title: [Help] How do I get a Java program to "silently" connect to a URL

Bad idea, You will be caught and then owned.
[/quote]Haha how naive.

How many times have I uploaded password stealing bots and reaped the rewards, too many to count. It’s easy to get away with it.[/quote]

You were banned for months and months, that’s not really ‘getting away with’ anything

item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

I agree, and to be frank, all you need to do to own your auth system is redirect it (either using bytecode or hosts), and replicate the server side login, which I doubt will be hard.

item.source: [Help] How do I get a Java program to "silently" connect to a URL

item.title: [Help] How do I get a Java program to "silently" connect to a URL
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

If anyone runs a packet sniffer on the running java app (which I always did when confirming old rsc bots if they tried to connect to some unknown ip), they will see exactly what’s being sent - just to let you know.

Also, what’s this auth system for? Hopefully its not overly important as from what I see, it would be way too easy to get past.

Read full topic
